climbs.name: Too Stiff To Tip
climbs.fa: Marty Karabin & Harvey Delos Reyes, Jan. 1993

content.description: Stiff moves get you to a somewhat high 1st bolt.  Continue some thin moves to the 2nd bolt, then up and out into daylight through a hole above.  Continue past 4 more bolts and much easier climbing to a 2-bolt anchor.
content.protection: 6 bolts with a 2-bolt anchor.  Note that this route has been retro-bolted and the original R-rating in the Queen Creek Guide has been dropped in the newer foldout topo.
content.location: Start inside the Pancake House and climb up and out the hole in the roof to the left of the cave roof.

climbs.name: Sunny-Side Up
climbs.fa: Marty Karabin & Harvey Delos Reyes (Karabin foldout)

content.description: 6 bolt face (Karabin pocket guide #32). On the upper face there are two separate lines of bolts (2 bolts per line). The left line of bolts look to be older, thus the maybe the original line?
content.location: Furthest route on the right side from the entrance to the Pancake House (Left of Over-Easy #33).

content.description: Thin climbing; after first four bolts it's possible to move a little right of the bolt line and stem your way to the top.
content.location: #33 on Karabin guide. This route is located in the southwest corner of the pancake house. First four bolts are shared with Sunny Side Up (#32), then last two bolts move right to a short face.

content.description: Short face climb from the tree
content.location: Before entering the pancake house turn left towards cool breeze and continue down the path. This climb will be second climb down that path.

climbs.name: L'eggo my Eggo
climbs.fa: Harvey Delos Reyes and Marty Karabin 93

content.description: Pocketed face climbing to less than vertical scramble to the chains
content.location: Turn left before entering the pancake house. This route will be the 3rd route down the path, with a large bolder at the base.

content.description: Start at the bottom of the crack just inside the Pancake House. Chimney up through the roof and into the offwidth. I was able to place a few nuts and a .5 C4 in a pocket, but none of them were great placements until I was high enough up the crack to place the #5. A #6 C4 might protect this route well. Follow the crack to the top and rap off of the anchor for French Toast. The Upper Devil's Canyon guide calls this route a 5.0. I thought it felt like a 5.7, some of that might have been because I climbed most of the route without any confident gear placements though.
content.protection: Standard set of nuts, #.4-1 C4's and a #5. A #6 C4 may protect the beginning of the crack well.
content.location: The obvious crack on your right when entering the Pancake House. In between Lumberjack and French Toast.

climbs.name: Hash Browns
climbs.fa: Harvey Delos Reyes & Marty Karabin, June 1991

content.description: Face climb to the first bolt, pass a small bulge, and then move past the 2nd bolt into a shallow dihedral.  Top out at 2 cold shut anchors.  Thin hands all the way up but great friction for your feet!
content.protection: 2 cold-shut bolts to two cold-shut anchors.
content.location: Short face climb on the left inside the Pancake House.

content.description: Face climbing to chains at the top out.
content.location: Turn left before entering the pancake house. this will be the fourth route down that path.

climbs.name: French Toast
climbs.fa: Marty Karabin & Harvey Delos Reyes, May 1991

content.description: The start of this climb is recognizable by two large pockets in the face. Start at the center inside the Pancake House under the roof and climb up to the 1st bolt and the 1st large pocket. Veer right toward the 2nd bolt and the 2nd large pocket and then continue straight up and outside to a thin face.  Climb the thin face past 2 bolts to a ledge and an anchor with 2 chains.  The Queen Creek Guide lists this climb as a 5.9 and the newer fold-out topo lists it as a 5.8 (probably due to retro-bolting eliminating the need to protect the lower face with cams.)  However, I thought the face climb past the last 2 bolts was still pretty stiff for a 5.8.
content.location: Center face inside the Pancake House.

content.description: A stiff little thing. After 3 bolts you're still not entirely sure what this route is asking of you. The climb does not surmount the roof of the Pancake House, engendering further disillusionment. Fun nonetheless.
content.protection: 3 bolts to a pair of shuts.

content.location: Farthest route to the left inside Pancake House. Route #39 on Karabin fold-out.

content.description: Facing Too Stiff to Tip, turn 180 degrees to observe its inverse circus mirror reflection. Deviled Hands is a 4 bolt sequence of fun, bouldery moves through the roof of the Pancake House via a chunky overhang.
content.protection: 4 bolts to a 2 bolt anchor. Bring slings to extend the anchor if you wish to set up a TR.
content.location: Pancake House, immediately on your left as you walk in.

content.description: Step up and out onto the exposed ledge.  One or two exposed moves gets you to the 1st bolt.  Continue up the exposed slab past 3 more bolts to the anchors.  Killer views and exposure!
content.location: At the entrance to the Pancake House, on the left (east) side of the corridor is a great view of the canyon and also the start of this exposed climb.

content.description: The Pancake House is a corridor and cave-like alcove with climbs inside that exit through holes above as well as some rap locations to access climbs on the outside of the Pancake House.  It's pretty much always shady, which is great in the summer, but the corridor can sometimes channel the wind on cooler winter days.
